awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Automatic Vascular Flow Reconstruction with Adaptive Three-Dimensional Doppler Ultrasound
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project includes the reduction in severe patient morbidity and elimination of hundreds of millions of dollars of expenditures by the U.S. healthcare system each year on revision surgeries and unnecessary procedures associated with late detection of post-surgical blood clots. Surgeons have the ability to prevent these catastrophic events, but only if the onset of the clot can be detected in a timely manner. Currently, of the patients who form clots after the targeted surgeries, half will suffer from a surgical failure due to the shortcomings of current modalities. This technology gives clinicians the ability to non-invasively track changes in blood flow within critical vessels to enable intervention prior to any compromise in health and prevent a majority of these catastrophic incidents. Beyond significant decreases in patient suffering and morbidity, such interventions will have an enormous positive economic impact on the health care system. This technology can also substantially improve clinical understanding of the clotting process and possibly enable non-invasive therapeutic treatments for these patients who otherwise would receive surgery.

The proposed project offers significant intellectual and scientific merit associated with new methods of ultrasound flow analysis. The objective of this work is to develop a system that is able to collect a 3D volume of ultrasound data and automatically extract the blood flow data in the region of interest by detecting an implantable component. This novel approach to measuring vascular flow will be the first to enable detection of localized post-operative clot formation rather than detecting clot-related issues via delayed and indirect methods that leave patients at risk for surgical failures. This technique can allow for intervention earlier than all other available methods, thus improving patient outcomes and reducing hospital costs. Furthermore, this method enables automatic detection of critical changes in blood flow, eliminating the risk of human error. Lastly, dissemination of the technology developed in this proposal represents an important milestone towards the creation of simpler, more automated ultrasound systems that can place this non-invasive, non-ionizing modality in the hands of non-expert clinicians for use in a broader spectrum of medical applications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Sonavex team, led by Xin "Ben" Kang, PhD, completed research for the award titled "SBIR Phase II: Automatic Vascular Flow Reconstruction with Adaptive Three-Dimensional Doppler Ultrasound." During the project period, the team created and refined a 3D automated ultrasound solution to enable healthcare providers without ultrasound training to collect critical blood flow information that can be used to diagnose dangerous vascular complications for at-risk surgical patients. Currently, collecting this blood flow information requires a Registered Vascular Technologist. Unfortunately, the nurses and dialysis technicians responsible for routine care of these patients do not have the specialized skill required to use conventional ultrasound and therefore are unable to collect this important information. Delays in detecting blood flow problems can lead to catastrophic complications for patients, which also have meaningful financial consequences.

The team pursued a novel approach to empower nurses and dialysis technicians to collect this essential information for their patients to minimize morbidity and cost. The solution includes an implantable vessel marker, 3D ultrasound imaging hardware, and a series of image processing algorithms to automate the complex procedure of collecting blood flow information.

During the project period, the team accomplished several key goals. First, Sonavex implemented a system to rapidly scan a three-dimensional section of tissue and find the blood vessel identified by the surgically implanted marker. Next, the team customized the ultrasound system and imaging settings to enable faster and more accurate blood flow information collection. Then, algorithms were developed to compute blood flow rate, diameter, and depth of the target vessel. The entire system was then validated using various simulated use models. Additionally, the team expanded the utility of the original solution to offer functionality specifically for the dialysis patient population. This included creating a permanent version of the vessel marker, merging multiple volume scans together to assess a longer vessel, and adding other vessel and blood flow parameters in the solution that may help predict vascular issues.

Completion of this work has enabled the team to receive initial FDA clearances for the technology and embark upon clinical trials of the device to demonstrate its impact on improving patients' lives and reducing the financial burden associated with vascular complications on the healthcare system.

 


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Xin Kang
